claims_to_validate.claim_text: The current Bayzat payroll system lacks automated salary calculation based on precise working days. The platform cannot dynamically adjust salaries proportionally when employees work more or fewer than the standard 26 working days.

The daily wage calculator in payroll settings intentionally overrides the formula configured in the leave policy for unpaid leave. The leave policy formula appears greyed out, indicating it is not active. This creates user confusion about which formula is actually being applied for daily wage calculations.

System failed to recalculate pending unpaid leave deductions when new salary configurations were created after leave request submission. Deductions were incorrectly based on previous salary configuration instead of current one, resulting in payroll deduction amount discrepancies.

The End of Service (EOS) gratuity calculator incorrectly handles leap years by defaulting to 365 days instead of 366 days for 2024, resulting in an inaccurate total service period and gratuity amount calculation.

Daily wage calculation for pro-rated amounts produces consistently lower amounts by 0.1 or 0.2 decimals. The formula (basic + allowances / 30) is configured correctly, but results in slight undercalculation across all employees' End of Service settlements.

System gratuity calculation (AED 231,821) slightly differs from manual calculation (AED 252,485), with detailed breakdown showing system uses a tiered calculation method (21 days per year for first 5 years, 30 days per year after, prorated for partial years)

The system's gratuity calculation may not consistently handle leap year days (specifically February 29th), causing minor discrepancies in service duration calculation. The system calculated 912 days, while manual calculation suggested 913 days by including the leap day.
System calculates days worked with a potential extra day (622 vs 623 days), which impacts gratuity calculation precision. The platform adds one extra day in length of service duration calculation.

System calculates leave salary using a fixed divisor in policy configuration, which may not align with user expectations about calendar days. User expected daily wage to be divided by 31 days, but system was dividing by 30 days, resulting in a slight salary calculation difference (2940 SAR vs expected 2988 SAR).

The daily wage calculator configured with 'working days' setting causes leave salary accrual amounts to fluctuate month-to-month due to varying working day counts. This leads to inconsistent cumulative totals across different months.

The system uses separate configurations for leave salary and salary proration daily wage calculations, causing different results. Leave salary uses a 30-day divisor while salary proration uses 30.42 days, leading to calculation discrepancies.

User initially misunderstood how working days are calculated based on work week configuration. The system was actually calculating correctly, but the user did not initially understand that their specific work week (NVK Operations) had all 7 days configured as working days.

The daily wage calculator fails to correctly prorate salary when an employee's departure date is in the future relative to payroll processing date. The system correctly prorates when departure date is in the past, but not when it's in the future.

When an unpaid leave request is approved and transaction submitted, then the daily wage calculation is changed and the transaction deleted to recalculate, the system creates duplicate deductions—one with the old calculation and one with the new. Moving the leave request back to pending/accepted does not resolve the issue. Even after deleting the unpaid leave request entirely, the unpaid leave deduction persists in payroll deductions.

When public holidays are added after a leave request is created, the daily wage calculation becomes out of sync between Payroll and Time Off modules. This causes incorrect deduction amounts that cannot be retroactively corrected.
The system calculates unpaid leave deductions using a custom daily wage divisor (30.42 days) instead of calendar days, which can produce deduction amounts that differ from user expectations

The system displays incorrect number of days in remarks for unpaid leave deduction in February, showing 31 days instead of 29 days (leap year), despite the underlying calculation being mathematically correct.

Global daily rate configuration overrides policy-specific unpaid leave calculation methods, potentially leading to incorrect salary deductions. The system calculates unpaid leave deductions using a global daily rate that takes precedence over individual policy settings, which can result in deductions based on gross salary instead of basic salary.

The system shows the daily rate from the payroll month (May) instead of the leave occurrence month (April), causing user confusion. The actual deduction amount is calculated correctly, but the displayed daily rate does not reflect the month when leave occurred.
Salary is currently based on a 26 working days per month standard: 365 (Days yearly) - 52 (Weekly off) = 313 / 12 = 26.08 working days
There is no synchronized mechanism for daily wage formula configuration between leave policy and payroll modules. Manual alignment is required.

Unpaid leave deductions are calculated based on salary configuration existing at the time of leave request creation. Changes to salary configuration after leave request may not automatically update pending deductions.
The system defaults to 365 days per year, failing to recognize 366 days in leap years like 2024
Pro-rated amount calculations consistently produce amounts less than expected by small decimal points (0.1 or 0.2).
Leave days are accrued at end of month, not prorated for mid-month departures
Unclear rules for counting service days, including whether departure date is considered a working day and how leap year days are handled
Daily wage is calculated using a fixed divisor of 30 days (Basic/30), which cannot be modified or configured to alternative formulas
Daily wage calculation follows a fixed policy setting that cannot be easily overridden for specific scenarios or month lengths.
Leave encashment daily wage is calculated using the number of working days in each month, which causes monthly variations
The system calculates leave salary and salary proration using independent daily wage configurations with different divisors.

Salary proration only works correctly for departure dates in the past, not for future departure dates.

The system cannot automatically recalculate salary deductions when public holidays are added after initial payroll calculation.
System uses a fixed 30.42 days divisor for calculating daily wage, which differs from calendar days
Daily wage calculations must use the actual number of calendar days in a month, particularly for February in leap years (29 days, not 31 days).
